abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Katowice Heat Supply
            and Conservation Project is rated as satisfactory. The
            project met its objectives of increased energy efficiency
            and good fiscal impact and benefits to the consumers. The
            project reduced pollution from coal-fired boilers resulting
            in coal savings and good fiscal impact and benefits to the
            consumers. The project has been a complex one involving five
            different municipalities, which caused initial delays.
            However, as soon as the obstacles were removed, the
            investment portion was highly successful. The financial and
            institutional sides of the project were not equally
            successful. Contrary to the other district heating projects
            in Poland, PEC Katowice did not address these aspects of the
            project in a proactive way. This, in combination with the
            tariff-setting framework in which they worked, resulted in
            delayed and inadequate tariff increases. Unlike the other
            district heating companies, the regulator had made Regional
            District Heating Enterprise Katowice use a very complex
            tariff structure with more than 60 tariff categories for
            which costs and revenues had to be calculated. The key
            lessons learned concern: a) demand forecasts, b) tariff
            policies, c) financial covenants, d) entity financial
            management, e) corporate governance, f) institutional
            development, g) reallocation of substation benefits, and h)
            involvement of local combined heat and power plant.
